intro: Giliastrum gypsophilum, commonly known as the desert gilia, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, which includes legumes, and is characterized by its hairy stems and showy, pink or purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. Its small, pod-like fruits contain seeds that are dispersed by wind, aiding in its propagation across dry landscapes. Giliastrum gypsophilum plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing nectar for pollinators in its native habitat.
